Rawls College of Business Administration''', also referred to as the '''Rawls College of Business''' or simply '''Rawls College''', is the [[business school]] of [[Texas Tech University]] in [[Lubbock, Texas]]. The college offers curriculum for both undergraduate and graduate students (including doctoral) and received its initial business accreditation in 1958 from the [[Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business]]. Established in 1942, Texas Tech's business school was originally known as the Division of Commerce. In 1956, the school was renamed the College of Business Administration. Following a $25 million gift from alumnus [[Jerry S. Rawls]] in 2000, the school was formally renamed the Jerry S. Rawls College of Business Administration.{{cite web|title=Texas Tech University|publisher=Handbook of Texas Online|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/TT/kct32.html|accessdate=2008-08-29}} The college is organized into five areas of study: Accounting, Finance, Information Systems & Quantitative Sciences, Management, and Marketing.{{cite web |url=http://www.rawlscollege.ba.ttu.edu/aboutus/welcome.asp |title=Rawls College of Business Administration: Welcome |publisher=[[Texas Tech University]] |accessdate=2011-06-09}} The Rawls College also offers [[dual degree]]s in conjunction with architecture, agriculture, foreign language, law, medicine, pharmacy, and environmental toxicology. The MD/MBA in Health Organization Management (HOM) allows medical students the opportunity to obtain both an [[doctor of medicine|MD]] and [[MBA]] degree over four years and is ranked by ''[[Business Week]]'' as 19th among such programs.{{cite web|url=http://today.ttu.edu/2009/03/rawls-college-of-business-programs-nationally-ranked|title=Rawls College of Business Programs Nationally Ranked|last=Cranford|first=Leslie|date=2009-03-23|publisher=Texas Tech Today|accessdate=2009-03-24}} The International Business program helps Rawls College students study abroad. In addition, the Executive Education Department develops seminars, conferences, and training programs for professionals and managers in business, government, and industry. ==History== {{See also|History of Texas Tech University}} Business classes were first offered at Texas Tech in 1927,http://www.rawlscollege.ba.ttu.edu/aboutus/facts.asp only two years after the university began holding classes in 1925. Established in 1942, Texas Tech's business school was originally known as the Division of Commerce. In 1956, the school was renamed the College of Business Administration. Following a $25 million gift from alumnus [[Jerry S. Rawls]] in 2000, the school was formally renamed the Jerry S. Rawls College of Business Administration.{{cite web|title=Texas Tech University|publisher=Handbook of Texas Online|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/TT/kct32.html|accessdate=2008-08-29}} ==Academic profile== ===Admissions=== ===Organization=== Rawls is organized into five areas: [[Accountancy|Accounting]], [[Finance]], [[Management information system|Information Systems]] and Quantitative Sciences (ISQS), [[Management]], and [[Marketing]]. ===Health Organization Management=== The Health Organization Management (HOM) Program is part of the Texas Tech University Rawls College of Business.[http://www.hom.ba.ttu.edu/About.htm Texas Tech, Health Organization Management website] The program teaches students about the business side of health care. It awards a degree in [[Masters of Business Administration]] in Health Organization Management, or MBA(HOM). The program conducts and reports research relevant to health care in the United States and recently Canada and provides services related to healthcare organizations.[http://www.hom.ba.ttu.edu/About.htm] The Texas Tech MBA(HOM) program is credentialed under the [[Association of University Programs in Health Administration]] (AUPHA) and [[Commission on the Accreditation of Healthcare Management Education]] (CAHME) accreditation programs. ===Rankings=== {{Infobox business school rankings | BWu = 92 | USNWRu = 52 | BWg = | Econ = | FT = | Forbes = | USNWRg = | WSJ = }} In 2009 ''Business Week'' ranked Rawls College of Business 92nd best among the United States' approximately 800 public business schools and 77th overall.{{cite web|url=http://bwnt.businessweek.com/interactive_reports/undergrad_bschool_2009/index.asp?sortCol=rankid&sortOrder=1&pageNum=2&resultNum=51|title=The Top Undergraduate Business Programs|work=[[BusinessWeek]]|accessdate=2009-03-24}} In the latest ''[[U.S. News and World Report]]'' Rankings of Best Colleges, the Rawls College ranked 52nd among public university business schools. ===Research=== ==Facilities== ===Existing=== [[Image:TTUcoba.jpg|left|thumb|Building exterior with rotunda]] The existing Rawls College of Business Building broke ground in [[1966]] and opened in [[1968]]. It has {{convert|200000|sqft|m2}}, 176 offices, and 36 classrooms spread across 13 floors, including a basement. The {{convert|208|ft|m|adj=on}} building is the third-tallest in Lubbock, and the tallest on the [[Campus of Texas Tech University|Texas Tech campus]].http://lubbockonline.com/local-news/2010-08-09/citys-tallest-buildings-wont-face-challenge-years ===Future=== [[Image:RCBA REND101607.jpg|thumb|Conceptual drawing of the new building scheduled to open in Spring 2012]] Construction is underway on a new {{convert|140000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} building to replace the current business administration building. The new facility will house modern classrooms, breakout rooms, student lounges, study areas, food service, and a career management center. The new [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]]-certified facility will incorporate leading edge technology into all offices and classrooms. The $70 million capital campaign for the project is co-chaired by Alan White, chairman and CEO of PlainsCapital Corporation, and Jack Hightower, chairman and CEO of Celero Energy. The new building is located on the north end of campus at the previous site of Thompson and Gaston Halls. The building was originally planned to be constructed south of the Merket Alumni Center, but was relocated after complaints from the [[Texas Tech Alumni Association]].http://lubbockonline.com/stories/051206/loc_051206050.shtml Other sites considered included the southwest corner of University and Broadway, where Weeks Hall is located.http://lubbockonline.com/stories/051206/loc_051206050.shtml The building will be constructed in Spanish Renaissance theme and will create new a north campus gateway. The process of clearing the site began with a ceremony on September 20, 2008.[http://media.www.dailytoreador.com/media/storage/paper870/news/2007/10/15/News/Regents.Decide.On.Location.For.Business.College-3030819.shtml?reffeature=htmlemailedition Regents decide on location for business college - News]http://today.ttu.edu/2008/09/new-rawls-college-of-business-home/ Ground-breaking for the new building took place in September 2009, and the building is scheduled to open in Spring 2012. ==Student life== ===Notable organizations=== [[Image:BGSlogo.png|right|thumb|140px|Beta Gamma Sigma key]] * [[Alpha Kappa Psi]] '''ÎÎÎ¨''' (Coed Professional Business Fraternity) * [[Beta Gamma Sigma]] '''ÎÎÎ£''' (International Business Honor Society) * [[Delta Sigma Pi]] '''ÎÎ£Î ''' (Coed Business Fraternity) * [http://rga.ba.ttu.edu/ Rawls Graduate Association] * [http://ec.ba.ttu.edu/ECA.asp/ Energy Commerce Association] * [http://tma.ba.ttu.edu/ Tech Marketing Association] * [http://aitp.ba.ttu.edu/ Association of Information Technology Professionals] * [http://www.orgs.ttu.edu/homsa/ Health Organization Management Student Association] * [http://financeassociation.ba.ttu.edu/ Finance Association] * [http://reo.ba.ttu.edu/ Real Estate Organization] ==People== ===Student profile=== There are 3,585 undergraduate students and 661 graduate students; 68 percent men, 32 percent women.{{cite web | url = http://www.irim.ttu.edu/ARCHIVE/ENR/COLLGBA.HTM | title = Fall Enrollment Since 1942: College of Business Administration | publisher = [[Texas Tech University]] | accessdate = 2010-07-13 }} ===Alumni=== {{seealso|List of Texas Tech University alumni}} {{Dynamic list}} *[[Angela Braly]] (BBA) 82'http://today.ttu.edu/2008/12/angela-braly/ *[[Samuel Ray Cummings]] (BBA) 67'{{cite web|url=http://www.txnd.uscourts.gov/judges/cummings.html |title=Judges - District Judge Sam R.
